title: MLB DFS Bargains: Monday 9/9
text:
Welcome to MLB DFS Bargains. We’ll split the analysis into three groups: very cheap, mid-tier, and expensive. A greater emphasis will be placed on the lower end of the price scale.

Please note, these player picks were organized early in the day. For MLB contests, always check lineups and weather closer to game time. Rain, wind, or unexpected managerial decisions could open up additional sources of value. Be sure to keep an eye on the MLB Headlines and Injuries desk.

Editor’s Note: Stay ahead of the competition from wire to wire with rankings, customizable projections, trade evaluator, exclusive columns and more in our Season Pass. And start using optimized lineups with our DFS Toolkit!

We have eight-games to juggle tonight.

DIRT CHEAP BARGAINS

Robert Dugger – SP – Miami Marlins (vs Brewers)

In his second major league stint, Dugger has made two successful starts. They lasted seven and six innings respectively. The overall profile isn’t especially awe inspiring. He doesn’t induce many whiffs, his command and control are roughly league average, and his stuff doesn’t limit hard contact or make hitters uncomfortable. In short, he’s a spot starter. He’s also priced so cheaply that it won’t take much for him to return value. Aside from a certain Mr. Yelich, the Brewers lineup hasn’t exactly torn through opponents. They’re a roughly league average offense.

Trent Grisham –OF – Milwaukee Brewers (at Robert Dugger)

Story continues

If you’d prefer to bet against Dugger’s mediocre skills, Grisham figures to be a useful foil. The 22-year-old crushed minor league pitching this season, but he’s scuffled since reaching the majors. He’s hitting just .222/.294/.389 with four home runs in 102 plate appearances. He’s posted baffling strikeout (28.4%) and walk rates (7.8%) given his reputation for above average plate discipline and contact skills. A start against a Triple-A quality pitcher should help him kick into full gear. He usually bats leadoff.

Abraham Toro – 3B – Houston Astros (vs Mike Fiers)

Toro has struggled to lift the ball since reaching the upper minors. He makes a lot of pulled, ground ball contact which helps to explain his current .265 BABIP (in a small sample of 55 PA). Besides the grounders, Toro has shown a major league skill set with plenty of plate discipline and contact ability. It’s just a matter of making some small adjustments. He has the fortune of facing a fly ball pitcher in Fiers. This should help with his launch angle problem – perhaps enough to furnish a home run.

Jaylin Davis – OF – San Francisco Giants (vs Trevor Williams)

Davis is one of the most interesting virtually unknown players to come out of the minors this season. In two Triple-A stops split between the Twins and the Giants, he posted a near-50 percent home run to fly ball ratio (HR/FB). For context, the best major league hitters top out around a 33 percent HR/FB. Davis is an extreme ground ball hitter who pummels the ball. By batted ball profile, I’m reminded of pre-breakout Christian Yelich. However, it should be noted that Davis lacks many of Yelich’s best qualities – especially plate discipline and contact rate. Williams isn’t known for allowing oodles of fly balls, but he does throw his share of clunkers. A few of the Pirates relievers are fly ball pitchers. Mostly, Davis is interesting for a chance to catch lightning.

Also Consider: Trevor Williams, Jaylin Davis, Travis Shaw, Isan Diaz, Abraham Toro, Anthony Bemboom, Luis Urias, Seth Brown, Josh Rojas, Nick Martini, Cory Spangenberg, Brandon Nimmo

MID-TIER MUST PLAYS

Michael Brantley – OF – Houston Astros (vs Mike Fiers)

If I have one regret this season, it’s that I’ve not used Brantley often enough. One of the most consistent hitters in baseball, he’s frequently overshadowed by his toolsier teammates. Tonight, he finds himself with an advantageous pairing against Fiers and a bizarrely cheap price tag. Like Toro, Brantley is a ground ball hitter. Advantage hitter. He has an elevated chance to homer coupled with myriad other ways to supply DFS value.

Also Consider: Zack Grienke, Franmil Reyes, Gleyber Torres, Yasiel Puig, Aaron Judge, Michael Conforto

HIGH PRICED VALUES

Jacob deGrom – SP – New York Mets (vs Diamondbacks)

Some plays are too obvious. And sometimes it’s nearly impossible to avoid these obvious choices. deGrom represents an excellent example of a too-obvious must-play. He’s the best pitcher in the slate by a wide margin, and he’s priced extremely affordably. Only a handful of players are a better dollar-for-dollar value tonight, and most of them are bargain basement, poorly-projected hitters.

deGrom’s matchup against the Diamondbacks is reasonably favorable. The Arizona offense is 11 percent below league average against right-handed pitching – most of whom don’t hold a candle to deGrom. While they’re not especially strikeout prone, we can still expect around seven innings and 8.5 strikeouts from the Mets’ ace. As an added bonus, CitiField is one of the most pitcher friendly parks in the league.

Also Consider: Yordan Alvarez, Pete Alonso
